title: 114_hr4783
content: The "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs from 2017 to 2022, along with administrative funding. Required expenditure amounts are also specified. The "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs from 2017 to 2022. It specifies required expenditure amounts for each fiscal year from 2018 to 2022. The Small Business Act is amended to specify required expenditure amounts for STTR programs from 2018 onwards, increasing annually until reaching 0.60 percent for fiscal year 2022 and beyond. The Small Business Act is amended to specify required expenditure amounts for STTR programs from 2018 onwards, increasing annually until reaching 0.60 percent for fiscal year 2022 and beyond. Reporting requirements are outlined in Section 4. The Small Business Act is amended to require annual reports to be submitted by December 31 and March 30 of each year to the Small Business Administration. Reporting deadlines are specified for various subsections within the Act. The Small Business Act now requires agencies to submit simplified and standardized reports to the Small Business Administration by March 30 of each year. Reporting deadlines have been specified for different subsections within the Act. The Small Business Act now mandates agencies to submit reports by specific deadlines each year, such as March 30 for certain subsections. Failure to report administrative funds by March 30 may result in consequences. The Small Business Act requires Federal agencies to report on the use of administrative funds by March 30 each year. Failure to submit the report may lead to consequences. SEC. 5. INDEXING AWARDS FOR INFLATION. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to adjust awards for inflation in Phase I and Phase II of SBIR or STTR programs. Phase I awards may not exceed $150,000, and Phase II awards are also adjusted. Phase I awards for SBIR or STTR programs are capped at $150,000, while Phase II awards are limited to $1,000,000. These amounts will be adjusted for inflation according to section 1908 of title 41, United States Code. SEC. 6 amends the Small Business Act by changing "is authorized to" to "shall" in Section 9(y)(5). SEC. 7 clarifies the eligibility of certain small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify the eligibility of certain small businesses under the SBIR and STTR programs within 180 days of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify that small business concerns described in subparagraphs (B), (C), and (D) of section 3(p)(3) are eligible to receive awards under the STTR program. SEC. 8. COMMERCIALIZATION ASSISTANCE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program, requiring covered agencies to implement a program to award eligible entities with a second sequential SBIR award. The program should not exceed 5 percent of the agency's total SBIR funds. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires covered agencies to allocate up to 5 percent of their SBIR budget for awards. The program will terminate on September 30, 2022 and includes a matching requirement for eligible entities to secure funding from third-party investors. Funding from ineligible sources is not permitted for matching. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires eligible entities to secure funding from third-party investors for awards. Funding from ineligible sources is not permitted for matching. Awards under the program may not exceed certain limitations and will be distributed during the Phase II award period. To receive a second sequential SBIR award, eligible entities must submit an application to the covered agency implementing the pilot program. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires eligible entities to submit an application with required information and matching funding details. Funds awarded can only be used for research and development activities that accelerate commercialization. Recipients are determined based on the potential impact on commercializing research and the feasibility of their proposed plan. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program evaluates applications based on the potential for commercializing research, technical feasibility, improvements to the commercialization plan, progress in Phase II activities, third-party funding expectations, and the likelihood of commercial and societal benefits. The Comptroller General is required to submit an evaluation report within 3 years of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Comptroller General will submit an evaluation report on the commercialization assistance pilot programs, detailing results achieved, commercialization rates, and growth in employment and revenue of participating companies. The evaluation report on the commercialization assistance pilot programs will include details on commercialization rates, growth in employment and revenue of participating companies, comparison of success with non-matching Phase II awards, demographic information, funds usage, third-party funding sources, program effectiveness analysis, and recommendations for program improvement if made permanent. The definitions for the SBIR program include terms like covered agency, eligible entity, eligible third-party investor, and ineligible sources, outlining criteria for small businesses to receive awards. The SBIR program defines ineligible sources as the awardee's internal research funds, non-cash funding like in-kind assets, funding from owners or affiliates, and funding obtained through loans or debt. SEC. 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to increase underserved population participation by using funds for outreach and technical assistance. Additionally, a conforming amendment removes the waiver authority for certain uses.
